title: 1D kinematics-acceleration with no change in speed

content.question: A cart is moving along a straight track and has velocity <math alttext="positive 0.5 meter per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> and positive acceleration at time <math alttext="1 second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math>. At time <math alttext="3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math>, the cart reaches a maximum speed. At time <math alttext="4 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math>, the cart again has velocity <math alttext="positive 0.5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>, but with negative acceleration. A student claims that the average acceleration of the cart between time <math alttext="1 second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math> and <math alttext="4 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math> time is zero. Is the studentâ€™s claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the final velocity of the cart is equal to the initial velocity.
Yes, because the cart returns to its original position.

No, because the values of the acceleration at time <math alttext="1 second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math> and time <math alttext="4 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math> are unknown.
No, because the cart spends more time with a positive acceleration than with a negative acceleration.

content.answer: Yes, because the final velocity of the cart is equal to the initial velocity.
